title: Reading: Civic Media and Public Opinion
subject: Civics

payload.text: Public opinion is shaped less by raw facts and more by which issues gain attention. Platforms reward emotionally intense content, so civic priorities can shift before careful deliberation happens.
When a topic appears repeatedly in major feeds, audiences interpret it as urgent. Agenda setting does not force beliefs directly, but it narrows what people consider politically important.
Recommendation systems can create repeated exposure to similar viewpoints. Over time, this reinforces in-group identity and increases distrust toward institutions or communities seen as outsiders.
Media literacy combines source evaluation, bias detection, and context comparison. These skills reduce misinformation spread and improve the quality of everyday civic decisions.
